awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope with EDS and EBSD Capabilities to Enhance Teaching and Research at Indiana University of Pennsylvania
awd_abstract_narration:
Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope with EDS to Enhance Teaching and Research at Indiana University of Pennsylvania

Scanning Electron Microscopes (SEMs) create detailed images of tiny objects. SEMs can image biological and geological samples and man-made items (modern and historical). With another instrument (Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy-EDS) attached it can determine chemical compositions. This grant will purchase an SEM with EDS for Indiana University of Pennsylvania. The SEM-EDS system will be an important tool for faculty and students at all universities and local industries in the region. The new instrument will enhance research and education capabilities in an underserved area of western Pennsylvania. The SEM-EDS will be used in scientific research and as a training tool for undergraduate and graduate students in a many science and technology fields.

With the ability to image objects at nanometer to millimeter scale, Scanning Electron Microscopes (SEMs) are the standard tool for scientific research of microscopic features. The addition of Electron Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) allows for collection of semi-quantitative compositional data and elemental mapping. This grant will purchase a research-grade ThermoScientific Prisma E SEM with an Oxford EDS system, along with some ancillary equipment, for Indiana University of Pennsylvania (IUP), which will be transformative to IUP and the surrounding region, immediately elevating research productivity of active scholars and their predominantly undergraduate trainees. The SEM-EDS system will be available for faculty and students at all universities in the region and to local industries, creating a regional effect, increasing research capabilities and productivity throughout western Pennsylvania. This grant includes senior investigators and their students from departments of Anthropology, Biology, Chemistry, Geoscience, and History who will use the SEM-EDS in a wide range of research topics, including: 1) quantifying crystallization within volcanic deposits (tephra, lava, and diabase sills) and lab crystallization experiments, 2) characterizing solid-state mineral chemistry and crystallography in semiconductor materials, 3) identifying diatom taxonomy to determine temporal variability of the silica and carbon cycles in both freshwater and marine systems, 4) analyzing Roman ceramics to investigate (pre)historic trade connections, 5) analyzing tooth-tooth interaction and tooth-food interaction in extinct (fossils) and living vertebrates, 6) characterizing ash morphologies from tree wood and nuts found at archaeological sites to correlate vegetation response to changing climate, 7) analysis of fine-grained aerosols (<2.5um) to examine air-quality, and 8) studying rapid tectonic exhumation. The acquisition of the SEM-EDS will immediately enhance the regional research environment by promoting new collaborations on campus, across campuses, and with industry and non-profit partners. The instrument will also be used as a training platform for undergraduate and graduate students to learn modern, state-of-the-art analytical techniques used in a large variety of science and technology disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of this project were to purchase a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) with Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) and create a new microanalytical lab to enhance the research capabilities for faculty at Indiana University of Pennsylvania (IUP), as well as our ability to train undergraduates in analytical research both in the classroom and through faculty-mentored projects. We have used the SEM to enhance the research environment at IUP by promoting new collaborations on campus, across campuses in western Pennsylvania, and with industry and non-profit partners.

The primary outcomes of this project are as follows:

  • Creation of a new microanalytical lab at Indiana University of Pennsylvania. Underutilized space in the basement of Weyandt Hall on campus was repurposed, cleared out and renovated in preparation for SEM installation during winter 2018-spring 2019.
  • ThermoScientific Prisma E SEM with UtlraDry x-ray detector (EDS) and other ancillary equipment were purchased and installed during spring 2019. The new SEM/microanalytical lab opened to researchers and students on May 21st, 2019.
  • During summer 2020 an Eaton 9155 8k Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) was installed. The UPS modulates the local power source for the SEM, protecting it from spikes and troughs in power, and provides a backup power supply in case of blackouts and brownouts.
  • During summer 2020, through the Applied Research Lab at IUP, we created an online survey to digitally track who is using the SEM, their experience levels, affiliations, the purpose of their visit, and to determine their satisfaction with the SEM lab. We also created a SEM webpage that serves to promote the SEM and its ancillary instrumentation.
  • 13 IUP faculty have been trained on the SEM and have used it to advance their research agendas. Our SEM users have come from a variety of disciplines including geology, biology, chemistry, environmental engineering, safety science, and anthropology. Faculty-led research projects have included a wide variety of specimens including submarine volcanic tephra, samples from experimental crystallization, mafic dike intrusions, diatoms from the Southern Ocean and from Pennsylvanian rivers, lakes, and ponds, molds of dinosaur teeth, water mite nymphs, a wide variety of plant pollen, anthropologic obsidian and shells, clay minerals, foraminifera, metamorphic rocks from Taiwan, biofilm from aquarium filters, industrial air filters, and much more.
  • 3 non-IUP faculty from regional universities and 1 Fulbright Scholar from Cameroon have come to IUP in order to use our SEM facility.
  • 12 undergraduate students and 2 graduate students have been trained on the SEM and have used it to complete senior research projects. Additionally, students (24 total) from a Mineralogy class annually complete mini projects during lab time analyzing real geologic thin sections to examine mineral textures and chemistry (EDS).
  • Approximately 100-150 undergraduate students have been introduced to SEM analyses through demonstrations in which they operated the SEM but were not fully trained in its use.
  • Approximately 30 high school students have been introduced to SEM analyses through demonstrations in which they operated the SEM but were not fully trained in its use. 5-10 high school students have been trained and used the SEM to complete science projects.
  • At the time of this report our SEM users have published 2 peer-reviewed scientific journal articles with 5 more manuscripts in preparation, describing research that included work using our SEM at IUP. SEM researchers have presented their work at 5 national conferences, with published abstracts and we have had 12 student senior presentations, all on work completed using the IUP SEM.
